etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in John Trevisa (c1342–?1402), translator. From Middle French pulsatif and its etymon post-classical Latin pulsativus exhibiting pulsation from classical Latin pulsāt-, past participial stem of pulsāre + -īvus; compare -ative

definitions: Characterized by pulsing, beating, or throbbing; = "pulsatile".
